The graphene (Gr)/PI (pyromellitic dianhydride (PMDA) modified g-C3N4) heterojunction was fabricated by a handy sonochemical method. After adding PMDA in the forming process of g-C3N4, the conduction position of obtained catalyst was lowered to −0.59 eV (closer to the Fermi level of Gr), which is beneficial for constructing high-efficient heterojunction with less energy loss. The photocatalytic efficiency of Gr/PI for Rodamine B (RhB) degradation was greatly enhanced compared with Gr/g-C3N4. The k of RhB removal on Gr/PI was 1.60 times as that of Gr/g-C3N4. The excellent photocatalytic ability of Gr/PI was mainly attributed to the effective separation of photogenerated electron-holes. Graphical abstract Unlabelled Image Keywords Gr/PI Heterojunction Band structure modification Visible light 1 Introduction Semiconductor photocatalysis has been gradually used in solving knotty environmental troubles using affluent solar energy [1,2]. Among kinds of semiconductors, TiO2 causes most people's widely attention because of its high photocatalysis activity, environmental friendliness and high stability [3,4]. However, TiO2 has correspondingly broad band gap (~3.2 eV), which limits its light response range to UV light [5]. Researchers concentrate on doping TiO2 with nonmetal/metal elements to broaden its optical assimilation to the visible light region [6–9], however, doping sometimes causes the formation of defect, serving as the sites for the recombination of photogenerated electron-holes. Consequently, it is imperative to look for efficient photocatalysts with broad spectrum response. Recently, graphite carbon nitride (g-C3N4) is deemed as a potential photocatalyst for contaminant treatment under visible light exposure [10,11], which has the advantages of high yield, low cost synthesis, chemical stability and narrow band gap (~2.7 eV) [12–16]. However, the high combination of photogenerated electron-holes restrains the photocatalytic ability of g-C3N4. Up to now, constructing heterojunction photocatalyst by coupling different type semiconductors (such as ZnO, WO3, Graphene, TiO2), and quantum dots [17–21] with g-C3N4 is an extremely efficient method to suppress the rapid recombination of photogenerated electron-holes, and this strategy has shown huge advantages for the improvement of visible-light photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4-based heterojunction photocatalyst. Graphene (Gr) is a 2D π-conjugation slice of carbon atoms combined through sp2-type hybridization, which has been thought as a superior candidate for the construction of heterojunction because of its huge surface area, appropriate band energy position (−0.08 eV) [22] and cracking sensitivity under visible light [23]. Liu et al. presented Gr supported Co-g-C3N4 nanocomposites displayed excellent photocatalytic activity. The electron-holes puddle generated on the interface of sheet between Gr and g-C3N4 effectively facilitated the electron transfer. But the conduction band (CB) position of g-C3N4 is at −1.40 eV, thus a lot of energy can be wasted when the photoproducted electrons shift from g-C3N4 to Gr. Thermodynamically, a lot of energy loss was disadvantageous to the heterojunction construction and photocatalysis activity of photocatalysts. Therefore, adjusting CB position is necessary to get suitable CB position for heterojunction construction. To modify the band structure, many researchers proposed to dope nonmetal elements or add some modifiers in g-C3N4 [24–27]. For example, Chu et al. engineered the band structure of g-C3N4 (named PI) by adding pyromellitic dianhydride (PMDA) into the network of g-C3N4, the obtained PI had lower VB position than that of g-C3N4 [10]. Meanwhile, the photooxidation ability of photocatalysts was enhanced after the decline of VB position. Inspired by Chu's work, PMDA with two electron-withdrawing anhydride groups is an extremely electron-deficient molecule. After the incorporation of PMDA into g-C3N4, the surface electron distribution of PI (g-C3N4 modified by PMDA) maybe changed. As a result, the band position of g-C3N4 could be effectively modified to realize the enhanced photocatalytic ability. Herein, we constructed a high-efficiency heterojunction photocatalyst between Gr and PMDA [28,29] modified g-C3N4 (named PI) via a handy one-step sonochemical method. Rhodamine B (RhB) was chosen as a targeted pollutant to measure the photocatalytic ability of preparated photocatalysts. The effect of band structure modification and heterojunction construction on the photocatalytic ability was discussed. Finally, the possible photocatalytic mechanism was proposed. 2 Experimental section PI: 5 g melamine was heated at 425 °C for 4 h, the obtained Melem solid [30,31] was grinded into powder. Then 1 g Melem and 1 g PMDA were mixed and calcined at 325 °C (7 °C·min−1) for 4 h. Finally, the product was washed three times with deionized water, and then dried at 60°Χ. CP: 1 g prepared g-C3N4 and 1 g PMDA was grinded adequately, and then obtained mixture was calcined at 325 °C (7 °C min−1) for 4 h. The obtained product was labeled as CP. The Gr/PI catalyst was fabricated by sonochemical method, detailed chemical compositions of compounds, the preparation of g-C3N4, Gr, and characterization section were listed in the supplementary information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural analysis The crystalline structures and phase constitution of the specimens were characterized by XRD (Fig. 1(a)). In the XRD pattern of Melem, some symbolic diffraction peaks appeared at 2θ = 12.5°, 13.0°, 25.5° and 27.0°, which indicated the successful preparation of Melem. Several new peaks of PI at the range of 15–30°(Fig. 1(b)), such as 2θ = 17.3°, 18.4°, 19.0° and 28.5°, confirming the production of new species due to an imidization reaction between PMDA and Melem, which was consistent with the work of Chu et al.. An apparent broad diffraction peak at 2θ = 24.9° shown in XRD picture of Gr, corresponding to the (002) diffraction plane of Gr (PDF-#41–1487). A series of weak peaks appeared in Gr/PI at the range of 20–26° belonged to Gr and other diffraction peaks belong to PI, which proved the successful combination of Gr and PI. g-C3N4 exhibited two typical peaks at 2θ = 13.0° and 27.5° in the pattern, showing the (002) and (100) lattice plane, respectively. Compared to g-C3N4, peaks of Gr were not discovered in the XRD of the Gr/g-C3N4, which might be ascribed to comparatively low diffraction peak and the low content of Gr. The surface groups on different samples can be demonstrated by FT-IR spectra (Fig. S1). The wide peak at 3283 cm−1 in the spectrum of g-C3N4 represented the NH stretching vibration modes. A battery of peaks at 1566, 1406, 1322 and 1241 cm−1 was associated with CN stretching of aromatic. And a spiculate peak at 809 cm−1 conformed to the CN stretching vibration of the triazine cycles [32]. For the PI and Gr/PI, their peaks were obvious weakening or shifting which different from g-C3N4, explaining that the addition of PMDA indeed influenced the chemical structure of g-C3N4 and formed new species. 3.2 Optical and electronic properties Proverbially, the optical absorption property is a momentous factor to respond the photocatalytic performence of the catalysts. The optical absorption of samples was recorded by DRS (Fig.S2(a)). The band gaps of samples were counted by the Formula (1): (1) αhν = A hν − Eg n where α, A, hν, and Eg are the absorption coefficient, constant, light frequency, and band gap energy, respectively. And value for n is equal to 1/2 for direct band gap material (Fig. S2(b)). From the Fig. S2(a), PI has a distinct blue shift compared with g-C3N4. Fig. 2(b) demonstrated that the band gap of PI was enlarged from 2.74 eV to 2.87 eV. The shifted absorption edge of PI indicates that the addition of PMDA can change band gap. Compared with PI, the DRS spectra of Gr/PI appeared obvious red shift, showing that its visible light response was enhanced after recombination of Gr. The enhanced visible light response was attributed to the powerful absorption of Gr for visible light, which was beneficial for light capturing efficiency of Gr/PI. The plat-band positions of samples were precisely measured by Mott-Schottky plot (Fig. S3), the horizontal intercept of the curve represented the plat-band positions of samples. The flat-band positions of g-C3N4, CP and PI were − 1.40 eV, −1.20 eV and − 0.59 eV (vs. Ag/AgCl, at pH = 6.6), respectively, which corresponded to −1.20 eV, −1.00 eV and − 0.39 eV (vs. NHE). The CB positions of g-C3N4, CP and PI were − 1.40 eV, −1.20 eV and − 0.59 eV (vs. NHE), respectively [33]. The obtained CB positions, combined with previous calculated bandgap energy, allowed us to compute the corresponding VB positions of samples [34]. The detailed VB, CB positions were listed in Table.1 . It was obvious that the CB position of PI was lowered from −1.40 eV to −0.59 eV, meaning the PMDA effectively reduced CB position. Compared to g-C3N4 and CP, the CB position of PI was much closer to that of Gr, thus the energy loss could be largely reduced during the process of photogenerated electrons transfer from the CB of PI to that of Gr. The less energy loss will be beneficial to the high-efficient heterojunction construction. In addition, the VB position of PI was also largely reduced to 2.28 eV. The lower VB position made the photooxidation ability of generated holes strengthened, resulting in the improved photocatalytic ability. 3.3 Morphology of Gr/PI TEM was used to observe the structure and morphology of samples. As depicted in Fig. S4(a), the Gr displayed 2D sheet with thin cicada's wing-like ripples and wrinkles. And PI looked like inhomogeneous substance with some small sheets stacked together (Fig. S4(b)), while the g-C3N4 (Fig. S4(c)) displayed homogeneous substance made up of big sheets. According to the Fig. S4(d), pleated Gr can be clearly observed at the edge of PI, which testified the successful integration between PI and Gr. Fig. S4(e) displays that g-C3N4 was also attached to the edge of Gr lamella. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of g-C3N4 and PI were evaluated by using the BET isotherms. The BET surface areas of g-C3N4 and PI were 30.13 cm2·g−1 and 48.73 cm2·g−1, indicating that the surface area of PI increased after PMDA modification. Large surface area of PI is beneficial for degrading BPA under visible light irradiation. 3.4 Photocatalytic performance The photocatalytic performance of photocatalysts under visible light (λ > 420 nm) is assessed by choosing RhB as the model pollutant. Obviously, the concentration of RhB was nearly unchanged within 180 min under the visible light illumination, meaning that RhB cannot be decomposed by direct photocatalysis. The adsorption equilibrium of photocatalysts reached within 40 min under dark (Fig. 2), and the RhB removal of g-C3N4, PI, Gr/g-C3N4 and Gr/PI were 25%, 27.2%, 25.7% and 26.2%, respectively. The degradation efficiency of PI displayed minor improvement by contrast with g-C3N4. The degradation efficiency of RhB with Gr/PI was 91.5% in 180 min, which outdistances that of PI (only 44.3%), supporting the advantages of heterojunction on the improvement of photocatalytic efficiency. Moreover, the RhB degradation efficiency on Gr/PI was twice as that of Gr/g-C3N4 (only 51.5%), suggesting the Gr/PI exhibited stronger photocatalytic capacity than Gr/g-C3N4. The RhB degradation process followed the pseudo-first-order kinetics. In the Fig. S5, the kinetic constant (k) of RhB elimination with PI was 0.0233 min−1, which was slightly rasied contrasted with that of g-C3N4 (0.0154 min−1), indicating that PI had better photodegradation ability which was ascribed to the enhanced oxidation ability of photogenerated holes after band structure modification. The k of RhB elimination with Gr/PI (0.0401 min−1) was 1.72 times higher than that with PI and 1.60 times as that with Gr/g-C3N4. The photocatalytic ability of Gr/PI was superior to that of PI, illustrating that Gr/PI accelerates the separation of photoproduced electron-holes, thus enhancing the photocatalytic ability. More significantly, Gr/PI exhibited superior visible-light-driven photocatalytic property to that of Gr/g-C3N4. The result might be owing to the lowered CB position of PI, which matched better to the Femi level of Gr and thereby reduced the energy loss during the heterojunction construction. The stability of catalysts is another vital property of the photocatalysts in terms of practical application. The stability of the Gr/PI was measured by reusing the photocatalyst for RhB degradation. After five cyclic experiments (Fig. S6), the photocatalytic ability of Gr/PI didn't decrease obviously, indicating that the Gr/PI owned good photocatalytic stability. 3.5 Proposed mechanism analysis Based on the above study, it was speculated that the photocatalytic ability improvement of Gr/PI maybe on account of the effective separation of photogenerated electron-holes. To verify this hypothesis, we tested separation and migration efficiency of photoinduced charge in semiconductors by PL spectra and photocurrent responses. The PL emission intensity of PI was weaker than that of the g-C3N4 (Fig. 3 ), meaning that the recombination of photoproduced electron-holes of PI was effectively lowered. The emission intensity of PI was distinctly lowered after compounding with Gr, demonstrating the advantages of heterojunction on the separation photoinduced charges. Compared to Gr/g-C3N4, the recombination of photogenerated electron-holes of Gr/PI was lesser, which maybe make the photocatalytic ability improve. These above results could be further evidenced by transient photocurrent response measurement. According to the Fig. S7, the Gr/PI exhibited a terrific high photocurrent response than PI and Gr/g-C3N4. The photocurrent density of Gr/PI reached 0.80 μA·cm−2, almost was 2.29 times as that of PI (0.35 μA·cm−2) and 1.78 times as that of Gr/g-C3N4 (0.45 μA·cm−2), indicating that the charges separation efficiency of Gr/PI was better than that of Gr/g-C3N4. Hence, more photogenerated electron-holes could migrate to the surface of semiconductor photocatalyst and add to the photocatalytic activity, and then improve the photocatalytic ability. Active species in the photocatalytic process are usually used to uncover the photocatalytic mechanism. Here, the quenching experiment was conducted to identify the role of active species (h+, O2 – and OH) in the photodegradation process. EDTA-Na2, BQ, and TBA were used as the scavengers of h+, O2 −, and OH, respectively. Obviously, the RhB removal was not obviously affected when EDTA-Na2 was added, meaning that h+ active specie was not the main active species (Fig. 4 ). After the addition of TBA and BQ, the photocatalytic degradation efficiency of RhB decreased from 91.5% to 39.4% and 21.1%, respectively, which indicated that both OH and O2 – played a leading role in the photocatalytic degradation of dye RhB. Based on above consequences, Scheme. 1 displayed a probable mechanism for the elevated photocatalytic ability of Gr/PI under visible light irradiation. The CB position of g-C3N4 was reduced from −1.40 eV to −0.59 eV via band structure modification by PMDA, and the lower CB position was much closer to the Fermi level of Gr. Once was irradiated by visible light, PI was excited. Because the CB position of PI (−0.59 eV vs. NHE) was more negative than the Fermi level of Gr, the photoproduced electrons which came from PI easily transfered to the CB of Gr, which followed the minimum energy principle. The photogenerated electrons on Gr would oxidize O2 molecule in solution to O2 −, which could oxidizes pollutant to CO2 and H2O. The fast transfer of photogenerated electrons accelerated the separation of photogenerated electron-holes. Hence, the recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes was largely limited. Lots of photogenerated electrons and holes could migrate to the surface of photocatalyst, and actively joined in the surface reaction. At the same time, the adjusted VB position of PI was reduced to 2.28 eV, which was more positive to that of g-C3N4 and, foremost, the VB the position of OH/H2O [35]. As a result, the H2O molecule could be facilely oxidized to OH with powerful oxidizing ability. The generated OH species also joined in the oxidation reaction with the pollutants, as proved in the quenching experiment. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, the high-efficient Gr/PI heterojunction photocatalyst with enhanced photocatalytic capacity was prepared via a handy one-step sonochemical method. The CB and VB position of PI were all reduced, the lower CB position was more propitious to high-efficient heterojunction construction, and the lower VB position had enhanced photooxidation ability. More importantly, the Gr/PI gave rise to the electron transfer from PI to Gr under visible-light excitation accompanied with less energy loss, which contributed to resultful photogenerated charge segregation, and in turn, the remarkable photocatalytic capacity. The kinetic constant of RhB removal on Gr/PI was nearly 1.72 times and 1.60 times as that of PI, Gr/g-C3N4, respectively. This work offered fresh understanding into constructing the high-efficiency heterojunction photocatalyst for effective removal of organic pollutants. coredata.dc:description: The graphene (Gr)/PI (pyromellitic dianhydride (PMDA) modified g-C3N4) heterojunction was fabricated by a handy sonochemical method. After adding PMDA in the forming process of g-C3N4, the conduction position of obtained catalyst was lowered to −0.59 eV (closer to the Fermi level of Gr), which is beneficial for constructing high-efficient heterojunction with less energy loss. The photocatalytic efficiency of Gr/PI for Rodamine B (RhB) degradation was greatly enhanced compared with Gr/g-C3N4. The k of RhB removal on Gr/PI was 1.60 times as that of Gr/g-C3N4. The excellent photocatalytic ability of Gr/PI was mainly attributed to the effective separation of photogenerated electron-holes.
coredata.dc:title: Band structure modification of g-C3N4 for efficient heterojunction construction and enhanced photocatalytic capability under visible light irradiation
